The club was established in Athens in 1924 by Greek refugees from [[Constantinople]] in the wake of the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919â1922)]]. Well-known players that have played with the club over the years have included: [[Rolando Blackman]], [[Ricky Pierce]], Giorgos Amerikanos, Giorgos Trontzos, [[Michalis Kakiouzis]], Nikos Hantzis, [[Minas Gekos]], [[Danny Vranes]], [[Ruben Patterson]], [[Kurt Rambis]], [[Jon Robert Holden|J.R. Holden]], [[Willie Anderson (basketball)|Willie Anderson]], [[Joe Arlauckas]], [[Anthony Bowie]], Claudio Coldebella, [[Jake Tsakalidis]], [[Nikos Zisis]], [[Kostas Patavoukas]], [[Nasos Galakteros]]. == History == [[Image:06012009050 Fedon Mathaiou.jpg|thumb|right|70px|[[Fedon Matheou]]]] [[Image:Kurt Rambis huddle cropped.jpg|thumb|right|70px|[[Kurt Rambis]]]] [[Image:Kakiuzis.jpg|thumb|right|70 px|[[Michalis Kakiouzis]]]] [[Image:ZisisNikos.jpg|thumb|right|60 px|[[Nikolaos Zisis]]]] ===Early History=== The large Greek population of [[Istanbul|Constantinople]], not unlike those of the other Ottoman urban centres, continued its athletic traditions in the form of numerous athletic clubs. Clubs such as '''Enosis Tataoulon''' ({{lang|el|ÎÎ½ÏÏÎ¹Ï Î¤Î±ÏÎ±Î¿ÏÎ»ÏÎ½}}) from the [[KurtuluÅ|Tatavla]] district, '''Megas Alexandros''' ({{lang|el|ÎÎ­Î³Î±Ï ÎÎ»Î­Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï}}) of Vathyriakos, '''Hermes''' ({{lang|el|ÎÏÎ¼Î®Ï}} â '''Ermis''') of [[Galata]], '''Olympias''' ({{lang|el|ÎÎ»ÏÎ¼ÏÎ¹Î¬Ï}}) of Therapia, and '''Kati Kioi''' ({{lang|el|ÎÎ±ÏÎ¯ ÎÎ¯Î¿Ï}}) of [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y|Chalcedon]] existed to promote [[Greeks|Hellenic]] athletic and cultural ideals. These were amongst a dozen Greek-backed clubs that dominated the sporting landscape of the city in the years preceding [[World War I]]. After the war, with the influx of mainly French and English soldiers to Constantinople, many of the city clubs participated in regular competition with teams formed by the foreign troops. [[Taksim Square|Taxim]], [[BeyoÄlu|Pera]] and [[KurtuluÅ|Tatavla]] became the scene of weekly competitions in not only football, but of athletics, cycling, boxing and tennis. Of the clubs in the city, though, football was dominated by Enosis Tataoulon and Hermes. Hermes, one of the more popular clubs, was formed in 1875 by the Greek community of Pera (Galata). Forced to change its name to '''Pera Club''' in 1921, many of its athletes, and those of most other sporting clubs, fled during the population exchanges at the end of the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919-1922)|Greco-Turkish War]], and settled in Athens and [[Thessaloniki]].[The history of AEK by Panos Makridis. Athlitiki Iho] Newspaper, 1953 AEK (Queen) Athens Basketball is the most successful among [[Athletic Union of Constantinople|A.E.K]]'s athletic departments. The obvious reason is that AEK's basketball team was the first ever Greek team to win an international trophy in any team sports. AEK won an unofficial championship played in Athens that was organized by the [[YMCA]], in 1924.Under Missas Pantazopoulos guidance AEK won the first club's championship in 1958. ===The First European Triumph=== AEK was the first ever Greek team to participate in the European Championships (now called the [[Euroleague]]) [[Final Four]], back in the year 1966. The Final Four was held in [[Bologna]]. Two years later, AEK was the first ever Greek team, not only to reach a European Cup Final, but also to win a European title. That happened back in 1968, when on April 4, AEK defeated [[USK Praha|Slavia Prague]] by a score of 89-82 in front of 120,000 spectators, 80,000 watching from inside the arena and 40,000 watching from outside the arena (the Guinness world record in basketball attendance).{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/45551/180/item |title=All-time attendance records |publisher=Euroleague.net |date= |accessdate=2010-09-30}} In 1970, AEK reached the [[Saporta Cup|Cup Winners' Cup]] semifinals where the team was eliminated by Vichy Basket, France, in what turned out to be the last year of the first "Golden Era" of the club's history. And that's because AEK dominated Greek Basketball in the decade of the 1960s, by winning the [[A1 Ethniki|Greek Championship]] 4 consecutive years in 1963, 1964, 1965, 1966, as well as in 1968 and 1970. In all winning the Greek Championship 6 times in 8 years. Over the next decades AEK lost its glamour, and managed to win only one trophy, the [[Greek basketball Cup|Greek Cup]] in the year 1981 under the direction of Coach Fred Develey, the American coach who previously was the head coach of Maccabi Tel Aviv and ARIS of Greece with super star Nik Galis. In addition to winning the Greek Cup in 1981, AEK was also a finalist of the Greek Cup in the years 1976, 1978, 1980, 1988, and 1992, but failed to win it in each of those years. ===The Queen's Comeback & 21st Century=== AEK made a come back in the late 1990s, when the team played in six consecutive Greek Cup Final Fours in the years 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, four consecutive Greek Cup Finals in the years 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, winning the Greek Cup in 2000 and 2001. In 2002 AEK won the Greek Championship for the first time in 32 years, becoming the first team to win the Greek Championship after having lost the first two games of a 5 game playoff series. AEK lost the first two games of the series to [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], but managed to win the next 3 games and take the series and the title 3-2. AEK also reached the Greek Playoff Finals in the years 1997, 2003, and 2005, and the Greek Cup Semi-Finals in the year 2006. In this same era, AEK reached again a high level in European competitions. The team reached the European Championship's Final Four in [[Barcelona]] in 1998, and beat [[Pallacanestro Treviso|Benetton Treviso]] by a score of 69-66, before losing in the final to [[Virtus Bologna]] by a score of 44-58. In 2000, on April 11, AEK won their second international trophy, the [[Saporta Cup]], by defeating [[Virtus Bologna]] 83-76. The next year, 2001, AEK reached the Euroleague semifinals, losing their playoff series there to [[Saski Baskonia|TAU CerÃ¡mica]] in 3 straight games.Due to many financial problems caused by the lost concern of the club's major shareholder in April 2011 AEK BC relegated from A1 for first time in club's history. ==Current Board & Ownership== {| style="text-align: center; background:white; color:black" |- !colspan="2"|'''Board of Directors''' |- |align=left|'''President & CEO''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Nikos Georgantzoglou |- |align=left|'''Vice President A''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Alexis Alexiou |- |align=left|'''Vice President B''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Spyros Papaioannou |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Georgios Chinas |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Michalis Palantzas |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Nikos Stathakos |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Vasilis Kapetanopoulos |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Georgios Katsadimas |- |align=left|'''Board Member''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}}Athanasios Michail"representing [[AEK Athens]]" |- !colspan="2"|Team Ownership & Amount of Shares owned(%) |- |align=left|'''Team Owner''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}} Ioannis Filippou 90% |- |align=left|'''Shareholder''' |align=left|{{flagicon|Greece}} [[Athletic Union of Constantinople]] 10% |- |} == Crest == In 1924, AEK adopted as their emblem the image of a [[double-headed eagle]] ({{lang|el|ÎÎ¹ÎºÎ­ÏÎ±Î»Î¿Ï ÎÎµÏÏÏ}} â '''Dikefalos Aetos'''). When AEK was created by [[Greeks|Greek]] refugees from [[Constantinople]] in the years following the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919-1922)|Greco-Turkish War]] and subsequent [[Population exchange between Greece and Turkey|population exchange]], the emblem and colours (yellow & black) were chosen as a reminder of lost homelands; they represent the club's historical ties to [[Constantinople]].After all, the double-headed eagle is featured in the flag of the [[Greek Orthodox Church]], whose headquarters are in Constantinople, and served as [[Byzantine heraldry|Imperial emblem]] under the [[Palaiologos]] dynasty.A.E.K.'s main emblem underwent numerous minor changes between 1924 and 2007.Since 2007 the emblem changed to the current shield design. == Colours and kit == The colours of yellow and black were adopted from AEK's connections with [[Constantinople]] and the [[Byzantine Empire]].{{cite web | url=http://www.aekfc.gr/index.asp?a_id=319 | title=Colours info |work=aekfc.gr| accessdate = 2008-03-20}} AEK's traditional away colours are all-black with a yellow stripe on the sides and home colours are all-yellow with a black stripe on the sides.AEK's kit manufacturer for 2011-12 is a famous greek company '''Nickan''' . ===Shirt sponsors and manufacturers=== {| style="text-align: center; The club used to play for 9 years (1995â2002 and 2006â2008) for all competitions at the [[Olympic Indoor Hall|Athens Olympic Indoor Hall]] (OAKA), which seats 19,250 fans, also played for two years (2004â2006) in [[Galatsi Olympic Hall]] with capacity of 6,000 fans, in Ano Liosia Hall (2002â2004) with 3,000 fans capacity, and in [[Sporting Sports Arena]] 2,200 capacity for the season 2008-09. For the season 2009-10 A.E.K played in [[Hellinikon Olympic Arena]] with 8.000 fans capacity. 01/2011âPresent |- [[Image:Panathinaiko.jpg|thumb|left|160px|[[Panathinaiko Stadium]]]] [[File:BasketballAt2004SummerOlympics-1.jpg|130 px|thumb|right|[[Hellinikon Olympic Arena]]]] [[File:OAKA1010436.JPG|130 px|thumb|right|[[Olympic Indoor Hall|Athens Olympic Indoor Hall]]]] |} ===Records=== *Record Guinness Book attendance: 80,000 tickets sold in [[Panathinaiko Stadio]]"Kallimarmaron" (Athens) at the game AEK-Slavia Prague, on 4 April 1968. ===Supporters=== [[AEK Athens]] has a large fanbase,the majority of AEK supporters are refugees or have refugee decent from [[Constantinople]] and people from the population exchange of the Minor Asia Catastrophe.'''Original 21''' is the largest [[AEK Athens]] supporters club. The first attempt to organise AEK supporters was '''Gate 21''' (formed in 1975), which took its name from the gate in the [[Nikos Goumas Stadium]], [[Nea Filadelfia]], where the most hardcore fans gathered.[[AEK Athens]] have also many supporters worldwide,most of them Greek immigrants,in places as [[North America]], [[England]], [[Australia]] and [[Cyprus]]. ===Rivalries=== AEK Athens biggest rivalries is with [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]] and [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]]. Against neighbours [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] they contest in the [[Athens]] local football [[derby]].The rivalry started because of the refugee decent of [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]] fans and by contrast [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] considered the classic representative of high class society of [[Athens]]. The rivalry with [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] begun from the different regions of Attica the clubs are from,AEK [[Athens]] and Olympiacos from [[Piraeus]].Another reason is that [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] except the working class fans have many high class & rich supporters. == Roster == {{Euroleague roster header |team=AEK Athens BC 2011–2012 | color1 = Black| bg1 = Gold| color2 = Gold| bg2 = Black}} {{player3 | pos =PG | num = | nat = Greece | first =Alexis | last =Falekas | m = 1.88 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =PG | num = | nat = Greece | first =Fotis | last =Vasilopoulos | m = 1.87 | kgs = | note = c }} {{player3 | pos =PG | num = | nat = Greece | first =Vangelis | last =Tzolos | m = 1.90 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =SG | num = 10| nat = Greece | first =Antonis | last =Mantzaris | m = 1.93 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =SG | num = | nat = Greece | first =Stavros | last =Kokkinopoulos | m = 1.91 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =SF | num = 5| nat = Greece | first =Petros | last =Noeas | m = 2.04 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =SF | num = | nat = Greece | first =Nikos | last =Kourtis | m = 1.97 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =PF | num = 12| nat = Greece | first =Evangelos | last =Sklavos | m = 2.02 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =PF | num = | nat = Greece | first =Thanasis | last =Magonis | m = 1.96 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =C | num = | nat = Greece | first =Dimitris| last =Despos| m = 2.08 | kgs = | note = }} {{player3 | pos =C | num = | nat = Greece | first =Aggelos | last =Siamandouras | m = 2.08 | kgs = | note = }} {{Euroleague roster footer | head_coach =*{{player||Greece|}} Dimitris Liogas * | asst_coach ={{player||Greece|}} Kostas Zervas | roster_url = http://www.aekbc.gr/DisplayITM1.asp?ITMID=3075 | accessdate = 2011-10-06 }} === Depth Chart === {| style="text-align: center; background:black; color:gold" |- !width="40"|Position !
